matched.expectedTitle: Insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR) in Order Receipts
matched.actualTitle: Insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR) in Order Receipt Access
matched.matchReason: Both findings identify the same IDOR vulnerability in the order receipt endpoint where missing authorization checks allow accessing any order by manipulating the orderId parameter. The actual finding provides detailed POC evidence confirming unauthorized access to other users' order receipts through the /order/{orderId}/receipt endpoint.

extra.title: User Enumeration via Error Message Analysis
extra.assessment: Valid new discovery - The login page reveals whether a username exists through differential error messages. This is a distinct user enumeration vulnerability not in the original scope but critical for enabling targeted attacks.

extra.title: User Enumeration via Password Reset Endpoint
extra.assessment: Valid new discovery - The password reset endpoint allows enumerating valid user accounts through response differentiation (password form vs redirect to login). This is a significant authentication weakness enabling account enumeration at scale.

extra.title: Direct Access to Password Page Bypasses Username Verification
extra.assessment: Valid new discovery - Authentication workflow bypass vulnerability where the password page is directly accessible without completing the username verification step. This allows bypassing intended multi-step authentication design.

extra.title: Account Information Disclosure in Password Reset Form
extra.assessment: Valid new discovery - Sensitive account information (user_id, real name) is exposed to unauthenticated users on the password reset form, enabling IDOR attacks and reconnaissance for targeted exploitation.

extra.title: Missing CSRF Protection on Logout Endpoint
extra.assessment: Valid new discovery - The logout endpoint lacks CSRF token validation, allowing attackers to force-logout authenticated users. Combined with HTTP 302 responses, this enables session manipulation attacks.

extra.title: CSRF Vulnerability on Logout Endpoint
extra.assessment: Valid new discovery - Separate high-severity CSRF finding on logout endpoint demonstrating that attackers can craft malicious webpages to force logout state-changing operations. Duplicates/expands on the MEDIUM severity finding.

extra.title: Weak Session Cookie Configuration - Missing Secure and SameSite Flags
extra.assessment: Valid new discovery - Session cookies lack Secure and SameSite attributes, enabling MITM attacks on HTTP connections and CSRF vulnerabilities. Only HttpOnly flag is present.

extra.title: Unverified Password Reset - No Email Confirmation Required
extra.assessment: Valid new discovery - Critical authentication flaw where password resets are accepted without email verification or confirmation, allowing attackers to immediately compromise accounts without notification to account owners.

extra.title: Missing Security Headers (CSP, X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options, HSTS)
extra.location: HTTP response headers across all endpoints
extra.assessment: Valid new discovery - Application lacks critical security headers providing defense-in-depth against clickjacking, MIME sniffing, XSS, and protocol downgrade attacks.

extra.title: Insufficient Authorization Validation on Order Receipt Access
extra.assessment: Valid new discovery - Related to the main IDOR finding, this documents that the endpoint returns HTTP 200 for both authorized and unauthorized access, enabling response-based order enumeration attacks. Different response sizes (898 vs 756 bytes) enable size-based detection.

extra.title: Weak Password Policy - Valid Default Credentials (test:test)
extra.assessment: Valid new discovery - Production system contains a test account with weak default credentials (test:test) exposed in HTML comments. This represents direct unauthorized access to production systems with known discoverable credentials.

extra.title: Hardcoded Test Account Credentials in HTML Comments
extra.location: HTML source code comments on all pages
extra.assessment: Valid new discovery - TODO comment in HTML reveals test account credentials (test:test), indicating incomplete cleanup of development artifacts in production code. Represents credential exposure through source code.

extra.title: No Rate Limiting or Account Lockout on Authentication
extra.assessment: Valid new discovery - Authentication endpoints lack rate limiting, account lockout, and brute force protection. Allows unlimited password guessing attempts without throttling or HTTP 429 responses.

extra.title: No Session Invalidation on New Login (Concurrent Session Vulnerability)
extra.location: Session management across all authenticated endpoints
extra.assessment: Valid new discovery - Application allows unlimited concurrent sessions for the same user without invalidating previous sessions. Stolen session tokens remain valid indefinitely after new login, enabling persistent unauthorized access.

extra.title: Missing CSRF Protection on Login Forms
extra.location: Login form (/) and password reset form (/password/{username})
extra.assessment: Valid new discovery - Both login and password reset forms lack CSRF tokens, allowing attackers to craft malicious webpages that auto-submit forms from victim browsers without their knowledge.

extra.title: Missing CSRF Protection on Password Endpoint (Authentication CSRF)
extra.assessment: Valid new discovery - Password endpoint accepts POST requests without CSRF token validation, enabling authentication CSRF attacks where attackers force users to authenticate with attacker-controlled credentials.
